query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Quando si parte il gioco de la zara, 2 colui che perde si riman dolente, 3 repetendo le volte, e tristo impara;
query.error: **English:** 1 When the game of dice is finished, 2 the one who loses remains sorrowful, 3 repeating the throws, and sadly learns;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Tal era io in quella turba spessa, 11 volgendo a loro, e qua e là, la faccia, 12 e promettendo mi sciogliea da essa.
query.error: **English:** 10 Such was I in that thick crowd, 11 turning my face to them, here and there, 12 and promising, I freed myself from it.
query.result: 10 Swylc wæs ic on ðære þreate þycce, 11 wendan me to ðam, and hider and þider, 12 and behetan me, and ðær fram ic alysde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Quiv’ era l’Aretin che da le braccia 14 fiere di Ghin di Tacco ebbe la morte, 15 e l’altro ch’annegò correndo in caccia.
query.error: **English:** 13 Here was the Aretine who from the arms 14 of fierce Ghin di Tacco met his death, 15 and the other who drowned while running in the chase.
query.result: 13 Þær wæs se Æretinisca þe of ðæra earmum 14 Ghin di Tacco hæfde ðone deað, 15 and se oðer þe adrencte on huntaðe rynnende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Quivi pregava con le mani sporte 17 Federigo Novello, e quel da Pisa 18 che fé parer lo buon Marzucco forte.
query.error: **English:** 16 There prayed with outstretched hands 17 Federigo Novello, and he of Pisa 18 who made the good Marzucco seem strong.
query.result: 16 Þær bæd mid ðam handum asprededum 17 Federigo Novello, and se of Pisan 18 ðe ðone godan Marzucco dyde strange.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Vidi conte Orso e l’anima divisa 20 dal corpo suo per astio e per inveggia, 21 com’ e’ dicea, non per colpa commisa;
query.error: **English:** 19 I saw Count Orso and the soul divided 20 from his body through spite and through envy, 21 as he said, not for any fault committed;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Pier da la Broccia dico; e qui proveggia, 23 mentr’ è di qua, la donna di Brabante, 24 sì che però non sia di peggior greggia.
query.error: **English:** 22 I mean Pierre de la Brosse; and let the lady of Brabant 23 take heed, while she is still here, 24 so that she may not therefore be of a worse flock.
query.result: 22 Petrus de la Broce ic mæne; and ðær geðence, 23 ða hwile ðe heo is her, ðæs wif of Braband, 24 ðæt heo ðurh ðæt ne beo of wyrsan heorde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Come libero fui da tutte quante 26 quell’ ombre che pregar pur ch’altri prieghi, 27 sì che s’avacci lor divenir sante,
query.error: **English:** 25 As soon as I was free from all those 26 shades who prayed only that others might pray, 27 so that they might hasten to become holy,
query.result: 25 Swa swa ic freo wæs fram ðam gedreagum eallum, 26 ðam gesceaftum ðe bædon ðæt oðre bædon, 27 swa ðæt hi ðæs ðy hraðor halge wurdon,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 io cominciai: «El par che tu mi nieghi, 29 o luce mia, espresso in alcun testo 30 che decreto del cielo orazion pieghi;
query.error: **English:** 28 I began: "It seems that you deny me, 29 O my light, as is stated explicitly in some text, 30 that a decree of heaven can be swayed by pious prayers;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 e questa gente prega pur di questo: 32 sarebbe dunque loro speme vana, 33 o non m’è ’l detto tuo ben manifesto?».
query.error: **English:** 31 and these people pray for nothing else: 32 would their hope therefore be in vain, 33 or is your statement not clear to me?"
query.result: 31 and ðas leode biddað ðæs ðinga ana: 32 hwæðer bið ðonne heora hyht unnyt, 33 ðe nis ðin word me wel andgitol?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 ché cima di giudicio non s’avvalla 38 perché foco d’amor compia in un punto 39 ciò che de’ sodisfar chi qui s’astalla;
query.error: **English:** 37 for the summit of judgment is not lowered 38 because the fire of love accomplishes in a moment 39 that which he who settles here must satisfy;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 e là dov’ io fermai cotesto punto, 41 non s’ammendava, per pregar, difetto, 42 perché ’l priego da Dio era disgiunto.
query.error: **English:** 40 and there where I fixed this point, 41 no defect was amended by prayer, 42 because the prayer was disjoined from God.
query.result: 40 and ðær ðe ic ðisne ende gefæstnode, 41 ðær ne wæs nan gebrec abedd mid bene, 42 forðæm ðe ðæt gebed wæs fram Gode atogen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Veramente a così alto sospetto 44 non ti fermar, se quella nol ti dice 45 che lume fia tra ’l vero e lo ’ntelletto.
query.error: **English:** 43 Truly, do not stop at such high suspicion, 44 if she does not tell you, 45 who will be a light between the truth and the intellect.
query.result: 43 Soðlice, ne stent ðu ðær on swylcum tweon, 44 gif ðe ðæt ne sægð, 45 hwa ðe bið leoht betwux ðære soðfæstnysse and ðam andgite.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Non so se ’ntendi: io dico di Beatrice; 47 tu la vedrai di sopra, in su la vetta 48 di questo monte, ridere e felice».
query.error: **English:** 46 I don't know if you understand: I speak of Beatrice; 47 you will see her above, on the summit 48 of this mountain, laughing and happy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E io: «Segnore, andiamo a maggior fretta, 50 ché già non m’affatico come dianzi, 51 e vedi omai che ’l poggio l’ombra getta».
query.error: **English:** 49 And I: "Sir, let us go with greater haste, 50 for I am not as weary as I was before, 51 and you see that the hill is already casting its shadow."
query.result: 49 And ic: "Hlaford, uton faran mid maran fyrhðe, 50 forðæm ic nu ne swince swa ic ær dyde, 51 and ðu gesihst ðæt se beorg nu sceadu weorpeð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 «Noi anderem con questo giorno innanzi», 53 rispuose, «quanto più potremo omai; 54 ma ’l fatto è d’altra forma che non stanzi.
query.error: **English:** 52 "We shall journey on from this day forward," 53 he replied, "as best we can; 54 but the outcome is different from what you propose.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Prima che sie là sù, tornar vedrai 56 colui che già si cuopre de la costa, 57 sì che ’ suoi raggi tu romper non fai.
query.error: **English:** 55 Before he is up there, you will see returning 56 the one who is already hiding behind the mountain, 57 so that you do not break his rays.
query.result: 55 Ær ðon ðe he ðær uppe sie, ðu gesihst eft cuman 56 ðone ðe ðær ær ða beorgas oferwrah, 57 ðæt ðu his leoman ne mæge forfleman.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Ma vedi là un’anima che, posta 59 sola soletta, inverso noi riguarda: 60 quella ne ’nsegnerà la via più tosta».
query.error: **English:** 58 But see there a soul who, placed 59 alone all alone, looks toward us: 60 she will teach us the quickest way."
query.result: 58 Ac geseoh ðær ðone gast ðe ðær ana 59 ana staðole stondeð and usic starað: 60 se ðe wile ðone weg wisian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Venimmo a lei: o anima lombarda, 62 come ti stavi altera e disdegnosa 63 e nel mover de li occhi onesta e tarda!
query.error: **English:** 61 We came to her: oh Lombard soul, 62 how you stand haughty and disdainful, 63 and in the movement of your eyes, dignified and slow!
query.result: 61 We comon to hire: o Lombarda soule, 62 hu ðu standest aloð and desdeignous, 63 and on ðinum eagena fare ðu art wurðful and slaw!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Ella non ci dicëa alcuna cosa, 65 ma lasciavane gir, solo sguardando 66 a guisa di leon quando si posa.
query.error: **English:** 64 She did not say anything to us, 65 but let us go, only looking 66 like a lion when it settles down.
query.result: 64 Heo ne sæde us nan ðing, 65 ac let us gan, ðurh ðæt heo lokede 66 swa ðæs leones ðonne he hine geresteð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Pur Virgilio si trasse a lei, pregando 68 che ne mostrasse la miglior salita; 69 e quella non rispuose al suo dimando,
query.error: **English:** 67 Yet Virgil drew near to her, entreating 68 that she show us the best ascent; 69 and she did not answer his request,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 ma di nostro paese e de la vita 71 ci ’nchiese; e ’l dolce duca incominciava 72 «Mantüa . . . », e l’ombra, tutta in sé romita,
query.error: **English:** 70 but asked us about our country and our life; 71 and the gentle leader began, 72 "Mantua . . . ", and the shade, all withdrawn into itself,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 surse ver’ lui del loco ove pria stava, 74 dicendo: «O Mantoano, io son Sordello 75 de la tua terra!»; e l’un l’altro abbracciava.
query.error: **English:** 73 rose toward him from the place where it had been standing, 74 saying: "O Mantuan, I am Sordello 75 of your land!"; and they embraced each other.
query.result: 73 aras him tógeanes of ðære stowe ðær he ær wæs, 74 and cwæð: "Eala Mantuanisc man, ic eom Sordello 75 of ðínum earde!"; and híg oðer oðerne clyppedon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Ahi serva Italia, di dolore ostello, 77 nave sanza nocchiere in gran tempesta, 78 non donna di province, ma bordello!
query.error: **English:** 76 Alas, servant Italy, hostel of grief, 77 ship without a helmsman in a great tempest, 78 not a lady of provinces, but a brothel!
query.result: 76 Eala þú þēowestre Italie, hūses sorgum, 77 scip butan stēorbord on micelre storme, 78 nā þēoden rīca, ac hordern!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Quell’ anima gentil fu così presta, 80 sol per lo dolce suon de la sua terra, 81 di fare al cittadin suo quivi festa;
query.error: **English:** 79 That noble soul was so eager, 80 just for the sweet sound of his native land, 81 to make a feast for his fellow citizens there;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 e ora in te non stanno sanza guerra 83 li vivi tuoi, e l’un l’altro si rode 84 di quei ch’un muro e una fossa serra.
query.error: **English:** 82 and now in you your living inhabitants are not without war, 83 and they gnaw at each other, 84 those whom one wall and one moat enclose.
query.result: 82 and nū on þē þīne lybbendan ne bēoð būtan gewinne, 83 and hī æghwæðerne ōðerne fretan, 84 þā þe ān weall and ān dic befēho.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Cerca, misera, intorno da le prode 86 le tue marine, e poi ti guarda in seno, 87 s’alcuna parte in te di pace gode.
query.error: **English:** 85 Look, wretched one, around the shores 86 your seas, and then look within yourself, 87 if any part of you enjoys peace.
query.result: 85 Loca, wrecce, ymb ða brimmas 86 ðine sæfearoðu, and ðonne on ðe selfne loca, 87 gif ænig dæl on ðe sibbe broceð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Che val perché ti racconciasse il freno 89 Iustinïano, se la sella è vòta? 90 Sanz’ esso fora la vergogna meno.
query.error: **English:** 88 What use is it to you that Justinian recounts the bridle, 89 if the saddle is empty? 90 Without him, the shame would be less.
query.result: 88 Hwat fremeð ðe ðæt Iustinianus 89 ðe brydel rehte, gif ðin sadol is idel? 90 Butan him wære ðin scynd ðy læsse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ahi gente che dovresti esser devota, 92 e lasciar seder Cesare in la sella, 93 se bene intendi ciò che Dio ti nota,
query.error: **English:** 91 Ah, people who should be devout, 92 and let Caesar sit in the saddle, 93 if you rightly understand what God notes for you,
query.result: 91 Eala ðu folc ðe sceolde beon æfæst, 92 and lætan Casere sittan on ðam sadale, 93 gif ðu rihte toc ðæt ðe God tæhte,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 guarda come esta fiera è fatta fella 95 per non esser corretta da li sproni, 96 poi che ponesti mano a la predella.
query.error: **English:** 94 look how this beast has become fierce 95 for not being corrected by the spurs, 96 since you laid your hand on the bridle.
query.result: 94 loca hu ðeos wildeor gewearð grama 95 forðæm ðe heo nære gebetweox ða sporan, 96 siððan ðe ðu ðine handa settest to ðam bridel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 O Alberto tedesco ch’abbandoni 98 costei ch’è fatta indomita e selvaggia, 99 e dovresti inforcar li suoi arcioni,
query.error: **English:** 97 O German Albert who abandon 98 this one who has become untamed and wild, 99 and you should mount her saddle,
query.result: 97 Eala, Þēodisc Albert þe forlæt 98 þās þe is geworden unþwær and wuduwæs, 99 and þu sceoldest stigan hire on bæc,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 giusto giudicio da le stelle caggia 101 sovra ’l tuo sangue, e sia novo e aperto, 102 tal che ’l tuo successor temenza n’aggia!
query.error: **English:** 100 may just judgment fall from the stars 101 upon your blood, and may it be new and open, 102 such that your successor may fear it!
query.result: 100 riht dom of steorrum fealle 101 ofer þinum blode, and sēo sīe nīwe and open, 102 þæt þīn æftergenga þæs ondræde!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Ch’avete tu e ’l tuo padre sofferto, 104 per cupidigia di costà distretti, 105 che ’l giardin de lo ’mperio sia diserto.
query.error: **English:** 103 What have you and your father suffered, 104 constrained by greed from over there, 105 that the garden of the empire should be deserted?
query.result: 103 Hwæt hæfð þū and þīn fæder geþolod, 104 for gītsunge of þanon gedrehte, 105 þæt þæs rīces wyrtgeard sīe wēste?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Vieni a veder Montecchi e Cappelletti, 107 Monaldi e Filippeschi, uom sanza cura: 108 color già tristi, e questi con sospetti!
query.error: **English:** 106 Come and see the Montagues and Capulets, 107 the Monaldi and Filippeschi, men without care: 108 those already sad, and these suspicious!
query.result: 106 Cumeð and gesih ða Montagus and ða Capulets, 107 ða Monaldis and ða Filippeschis, weras butan caru: 108 ða earmlican ða, and ðas mid ðam orsorgum!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Vien, crudel, vieni, e vedi la pressura 110 d’i tuoi gentili, e cura lor magagne; 111 e vedrai Santafior com’ è oscura!
query.error: **English:** 109 Come, cruel one, come and see the oppression 110 of your nobles, and heal their suffering; 111 and you will see how obscure Santafior is!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Vieni a veder la tua Roma che piagne 113 vedova e sola, e dì e notte chiama: 114 «Cesare mio, perché non m’accompagne?».
query.error: **English:** 112 Come and see your Rome that weeps, 113 widowed and alone, and day and night she calls out: 114 "My Caesar, why do you not accompany me?".
query.result: 112 Cumeð and gesih ðinne Rome ðe wepeð, 113 wuduwe and ana, and dæges and nihtes cleopað: 114 "Mín Casere, hwi ne gefylst ðu me?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Vieni a veder la gente quanto s’ama! 116 e se nulla di noi pietà ti move, 117 a vergognar ti vien de la tua fama.
query.error: **English:** 115 Come and see how much people love each other! 116 And if no pity for us moves you, 117 come to be ashamed of your fame.
query.result: 115 Cumeðandgeseohuðætmænigmanlufað! 116 andgifnænreowðinæfrenebewegað, 117 cumeðandbesceamiaoðinrehlaðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 E se licito m’è, o sommo Giove 119 che fosti in terra per noi crucifisso, 120 son li giusti occhi tuoi rivolti altrove?
query.error: **English:** 118 And if it is permissible for me, O supreme Jove, 119 who were crucified on earth for us, 120 are your just eyes turned elsewhere?
query.result: 118 And gif hit me aliefed is, ðu hehsta Iuppiter, 119 ðe ðu on eorðan wære for usum synnum on rode fæstnod, 120 sint ðine rihtwise eagan elles hwearfende?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 O è preparazion che ne l’abisso 122 del tuo consiglio fai per alcun bene 123 in tutto de l’accorger nostro scisso?
query.error: **English:** 121 Or is it a preparation that you make in the abyss 122 of your counsel for some good 123 entirely beyond our understanding?
query.result: 121 Oððe is hit gegearwod ðæt ðu on ðæs abysse grund 122 ðines geðohtes wyrce sume gōde 123 ðe we mid ealle urum andgiete ne magon ongietan?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Ché le città d’Italia tutte piene 125 son di tiranni, e un Marcel diventa 126 ogne villan che parteggiando viene.
query.error: **English:** 124 For all the cities of Italy are full 125 of tyrants, and every peasant who joins a faction 126 becomes a Marcellus.
query.result: 124 Forðæm ðe ealle ða burga on Italia lande 125 sint afyllede mid tyrranum, and ælc unlæred ceorl ðe on facne cymð 126 wyrð Marcillus gehaten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Fiorenza mia, ben puoi esser contenta 128 di questa digression che non ti tocca, 129 mercé del popol tuo che si argomenta.
query.error: **English:** 127 My Florence, you can be well content 128 with this digression that does not touch you, 129 thanks to your people who are striving.
query.result: 127 Florentia min, ðu miht wel beon bliðe 128 ðisse digressiun ðe ðe ne tihð, 129 ðurh ðin folc ðe ðe swinkeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Molti han giustizia in cuore, e tardi scocca 131 per non venir sanza consiglio a l’arco; 132 ma il popol tuo l’ha in sommo de la bocca.
query.error: **English:** 130 Many have justice in their hearts, and shoot late 131 so as not to come to the bow without counsel; 132 but your people have it on the tip of their tongues.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Molti rifiutan lo comune incarco; 134 ma il popol tuo solicito risponde 135 sanza chiamare, e grida: «I’ mi sobbarco!».
query.error: **English:** 133 Many refuse the common burden; 134 but your people eagerly respond 135 without being called, and cry: "I take it upon myself!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Or ti fa lieta, ché tu hai ben onde: 137 tu ricca, tu con pace e tu con senno! 138 S’io dico ’l ver, l’effetto nol nasconde.
query.error: **English:** 136 Now be joyful, for you have good reason: 137 you are wealthy, you have peace, and you have wisdom! 138 If I speak the truth, the result does not hide it.
query.result: 136 Nu ðu ðe gefean, forðæm ðu hæfst wel hwanon: 137 ðu eart welig, ðu eart on sibbe and ðu eart on geðeahte! 138 Gif ic ðæt soð secge, ðæt geweorc ðæt ne hylt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Atene e Lacedemona, che fenno 140 l’antiche leggi e furon sì civili, 141 fecero al viver bene un picciol cenno
query.error: **English:** 139 Athens and Lacedaemon, which made 140 the ancient laws and were so civilized, 141 made but a small contribution to the good life
query.result: 139 Aðenas and Lacedæmonia, ða ðe worhton 140 ða ealdan laga and wæron swa gesibbe, 141 dydon lytel tacen to ðam godan life

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 verso di te, che fai tanto sottili 143 provedimenti, ch’a mezzo novembre 144 non giugne quel che tu d’ottobre fili.
query.error: **English:** 142 compared to you, who make such subtle 143 provisions that what you spin in October 144 does not last until mid-November.
query.result: 142 wið ðe, ðe ðu wyrcst swa mænige gleawe 143 gesetnessa, ðæt on middum monde 144 ne mæg ðæt ðolian ðæt ðu ðinum fingrum wyrcst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 Quante volte, del tempo che rimembre, 146 legge, moneta, officio e costume 147 hai tu mutato, e rinovate membre!
query.error: **English:** 145 How many times, since the time that you can remember, 146 have you changed laws, currency, officials, and customs, 147 and renewed your members!
query.result: 145 Hu oft, siððan ðe ðu rixian ongunne, 146 lage, and mone, and mæð and geþeaw, 147 and ðine leode lyt þurh ðine lare!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
148 E se ben ti ricordi e vedi lume, 149 vedrai te somigliante a quella inferma 150 che non può trovar posa in su le piume,
query.error: **English:** 148 And if you remember well and see clearly, 149 you will see yourself resembling that sick woman 150 who cannot find rest on her bed,
query.result: 148 And gif ðu ðæt geþencan meaht, and ðæt geondþencan, 149 ðu miht ðe selfne geseon ðære gelicost, 150 ðe ðære untrumon ðe ðære earfeðnysse,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 ma con dar volta suo dolore scherma.
query.error: **English:** 151 but tries to alleviate her pain by tossing and turning.
query.result: 151 ðe heo on ðam bedde ne mæg gerestan,
